title: Johann Ulrich Steigleder
text:
Johann Ulrich Steigleder (22 March 1593 – 10 October 1635) was a German <a href="Baroque%20music">Baroque</a> composer and <a href="organist">organist</a>. He was the most celebrated member of the Steigleder family, which also included Adam Steigleder (1561–1633), his father, and Utz Steigleder (died 1581), his grandfather.
Steigleder was born in <a href="Schw%C3%A4bisch%20Hall">Schwäbisch Hall</a> on 22 March 1593. He was instructed in music by his father Adam, whose teacher was the then-famous <a href="Simon%20Lohet">Simon Lohet</a>. In 1613 he became organist of Stephanskirche in <a href="Lindau">Lindau</a>, on <a href="Lake%20Constance">Lake Constance</a>; then in 1617 he left Lindau for Stuttgart, where he became organist of the <a href="Stiftskirche%2C%20Stuttgart">Stiftskirche</a> the same year. In 1627 Steigleder was appointed ducal organist at the <a href="W%C3%BCrttemberg">Württemberg</a> court. While in Stuttgart, he may have taught, among others, <a href="Johann%20Jakob%20Froberger">Johann Jakob Froberger</a>. He died of <a href="Bubonic%20plague">plague</a> in 1635 in the midst of the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a>.
Steigleder's most important works are his two published collections of organ pieces. The first, "Ricercar tabulatura" of 1624 (published at Stuttgart), introduced a number of important innovations. It was the first German music collection to be published using engraved <a href="copper">copper</a> plates (the title page indicates that the composer did the engraving himself). It was also, together with <a href="Samuel%20Scheidt">Scheidt</a>'s "Tabulatura nova", one of the first German printed collections to adopt five-line notation with <a href="Note%20%28music%29">note</a>s instead of letter notation. Finally, Steigleder was among the first to make the transition from modal indications such as "primi toni", "secundi toni", etc. to <a href="Key%20%28music%29">keys</a> in keyboard music. "Ricercar tabulatura" consists of 12 <a href="ricercar">ricercar</a>s that explore a wide range of techniques and models, from simple monothematic works to pieces with double subjects, several sections, etc.; some are inspired by <a href="Jan%20Pieterszoon%20Sweelinck">Sweelinck</a> in their structure and/or use of <a href="diminution">diminution</a> and <a href="augmentation%20%28music%29">augmentation</a>. One of the ricercars contains a long interlude built on imitation of <a href="cuckoo">cuckoo</a>'s call, like <a href="Girolamo%20Frescobaldi">Frescobaldi</a>'s and <a href="Johann%20Kaspar%20Kerll">Kerll</a>'s <a href="Capriccio%20%28music%29">capriccios</a> "sopra Cucu".
Steigleder's "Tabulaturbuch" (<a href="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a>, 1627) consists of 40 <a href="Variation%20form">variation</a>s on Luther's chorale "<a href="Vater%20unser%20im%20Himmelreich">Vater unser im Himmelreich</a>". This collection was intended for the church organist, and Steigleder specifically states that the performer may choose how many variations to play, which ones and in what sequence. Certain variations call for a supporting instrument or singer to reinforce the chorale melody. Steigleder employs a vast array of techniques from simple 2 voice settings to <a href="double%20counterpoint">double counterpoint</a>, extensive multi-sectional fantasies and toccatas, various <a href="Canon%20%28music%29">canon</a>s, <a href="hocket">hocket</a>, and many more.
In part because of his early death Steigleder did not exert much influence over the development of keyboard music in Europe. Thematic connections with his work, however, were found in <a href="Johann%20Jakob%20Froberger">Froberger</a>'s music.
Discography.
"Ricercar Tabulatura" 1624. Organist: Olimpio Medori, SS. Annunziata organ, Florence (Cornetto, 2004)
"Meantone Steigleder : Ricercar Tabulatura" 1624. Organist: Gary Verkade. The Grönlund organ in Norrfjärden church, Sweden (Euridice, 2016)
